case_data.name: International Partners For Ethical Care Inc v. Inslee
case_data.summary: [This summary is temporary while we research the case]. On August 16, 2023, two national organizations—International Partners for Ethical Care, Inc. (IPEC) and Advocates Protecting Children (APC)—along with several Washington parents challenged three state laws: (1) Wash. Rev. Code § 71.34.530, allowing minors age 13 and older to seek outpatient mental health treatment without parental consent; (2) ESSB 5599 (2023), which limits parental notification when minors seek “protected health care services,” including gender-affirming care; and (3) SHB 1406 (2023), which expands shelter services allowing minors to remain in licensed shelters without parental permission under certain conditions. Plaintiffs alleged these laws violated the Due Process, Free Exercise, and Free Speech Clauses.

Case 3:23-cv-05736-DGE   Document 1   Filed 08/16/23   Page 1 of 35
 
1     
2 
3

5  In The United States District Court 
For The Western District Of Washington 
6 
 
International Partners For   
7 
Ethical Care, Inc., Advocates 
Protecting Children, Parent 1a, 
8 
Parent 1b, Parent 2a, Parent 2b, 
Parent 3a, Parent 3b, Parent 4a, and 
9 
Parent 4b, 
 
10 
Plaintiffs,   
   
11 
v.    No. 3:23-cv-5736 
     
12 
Jay Inslee, Governor of Washington, in his  Complaint  
official capacity; Robert Ferguson,   
13 
 
Attorney General of Washington, in his official 
14 capacity; and Ross Hunter, Secretary of the 
Washington Department of Children, Youth, 
15 
and Families, in his official capacity,  
16   
Defendants. 
17 
 
18   
19  I.  Introduction 
20  1.  This lawsuit against Washington state officials is about whether a minor child who 
21  is receiving or even just seeking so-called “gender-affirming” treatment—which includes services 
22  that alter body parts, prescribe life-altering medications, and other related things—showing up at 
23  a youth shelter, homeless shelter, or a host home, provides sufficient grounds to steamroll parental 
24  constitutional rights. Under recently enacted SB 5599, that answer is “yes.” Under the United 
25  States Constitution and the Washington State Constitution, however, that answer is “no.”  
26  2.  This lawsuit challenges Engrossed Senate Substitute Bill (SB) 5599 of the 2023 
27  Regular Session of the 68th Legislature of Washington State, which is codified in relevant part at 
 
Complaint - 1  Ard Law Group PLLC 
IPEC v. Inslee, No. 3:23-cv-5736  P.O. Box 11633 
Bainbridge Island, WA 98110 
Phone: (206) 701-9243 
 
 

Case 3:23-cv-05736-DGE   Document 1   Filed 08/16/23   Page 2 of 35
 
1  Revised Code of Washington (Wash. Rev. Code.) § 13.32A.082(3), and took effect July 23, 2023. 
2  The statute infringes on parental constitutional rights. 
3  3.  It takes away a requirement of notice to parents.  
4  4.  It authorizes the State to refer a minor for “behavioral health services” without 
5  defining what that entails, potentially meaning that a minor could receive—at least—mental health 
6  services that the parents would not endorse, and arguably also medical treatment that the parents 
7  would not authorize. There is no age minimum in SB 5599 for such services. 
8  5.  SB 5599 also delays when parents can get their children back from the State’s 
9  control. 
10  6.  In short, this statute allows shelters and homes to keep children at locations without 
11  their parents’ knowledge and refer those children for health interventions without their parents’ 
12  knowledge or approval. It does not require children to be returned on any particular timetable or 
13  under any particular conditions.  
14  7.  This suit is thus brought as a pre-enforcement challenge against statewide officials, 
15  in their official capacities, over this new Washington statute that discriminatorily deprives certain 
16  parents—but not all parents—of their fundamental right under the U.S. Constitution to direct the 
17  care and upbringing of their children, as well as their rights to the free exercise of religion, due 
18  process, free speech, and equal protection. Plaintiffs bring this suit pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1983 
19  because Defendants are acting under color of state law in violating Plaintiffs’ rights under the First 
20  and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution.  
21  II.  Parties.  
22  8.  Plaintiff International Partners for Ethical Care, Inc., is a nonprofit organization 
23  incorporated in the State of Illinois and recognized as a charitable or educational public benefit 
24  organization under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. The organization’s “mission 
25  is to stop the unethical treatment of children by schools, hospitals, and mental and medical 
26  healthcare providers under the duplicitous banner of gender identity affirmation.” Partners for 
27  Ethical Care Homepage, https://tinyurl.com/4nrp5vn9 (last visited Aug. 15, 2023). Members of 
 
Complaint - 2  Ard Law Group PLLC 
IPEC v. Inslee, No. 3:23-cv-5736  P.O. Box 11633 
Bainbridge Island, WA 98110 
Phone: (206) 701-9243 
 
 

Case 3:23-cv-05736-DGE   Document 1   Filed 08/16/23   Page 3 of 35
 
1  this organization include approximately two dozen parents in the State of Washington, including 
2  at least one resident of the State of Washington who is a parent in the state with a transgender 
3  minor child. 
4  9.  Advocates  Protecting  Children  is  a  nonprofit  501(c)(3)  organization.  It  is 
5  “dedicated to fighting the gender industry, and especially its predation on children in the form of 
6  unethical social and medical transition for the sake of political and financial profit.” About Us, 
7  Advocates Protecting Children, https://tinyurl.com/3kun8vf2 (last visited Aug. 16, 2023). 
8  10.  Parent 1A is a citizen of Washington and the mother of a 14-year-old biological girl 
9  who previously identified as a boy, whom we will call 1C.  
10  11.  Parent  1B  is  the  husband  of  Parent  1A  and  father  of  1C.  He  is  a  citizen  of 
11  Washington.  
12  12.  The prior gender transition of 1C took place at school, unbeknownst to her parents, 
13  where the school encouraged the transition, including through meeting for two and a half months 
14  with a school counselor. 1C, after being removed from public school, de-transitioned and now again 
15  identifies as a girl. But 1A and 1B believe that when they put 1C back in school this fall, through the 
16  school’s efforts which the school kept hidden from 1A and 1B, 1C will transition again and run away 
17  from home. 
18  13.  Parent 2A is the mother of two transgender children: 2C, a biological girl who 
19  identifies as a boy and recently turned age 18, and 2D, another biological girl who identifies as a 
20  boy, is age 13. 2A is a citizen of Washington.  
21  14.  Parent 2B is the husband of Parent 2A, the father of 2C and 2D, and a citizen of 
22  Washington.  
23  15.  Parent 3A is the mother of a transgender child, 3C, a 14-year-old biological boy who 
24  identifies as a girl. 3C is also autistic. 3A is a citizen of Washington.  
25  16.  Parent 3B is the husband of Parent 3A and the father of 3C. He is a citizen of 
26  Washington.  
27 
 
Complaint - 3  Ard Law Group PLLC 
IPEC v. Inslee, No. 3:23-cv-5736  P.O. Box 11633 
Bainbridge Island, WA 98110 
Phone: (206) 701-9243 
 
 

Case 3:23-cv-05736-DGE   Document 1   Filed 08/16/23   Page 4 of 35
 
1  17.  3A and 3B are Roman Catholic. They believe in the teachings of the Roman Catholic 
2  Church on gender transitions and identity.  
3  18.  Parent 4A is the mother of three children, including 4C, who is an eight-year-old 
4  girl, and 4D, a six-year-old boy. 4A is a citizen of Washington.  
5  19.  Parent 4B is the husband of 4A and the father of 4C and 4D. He is a citizen of 
6  Washington.  
7  20.  4A and 4B are non-denominational Christians who believe the Bible is the Word of 
8  God and, as such, is authoritative on every issue to which it speaks. They believe the topics on 
9  which the Bible provides teachings include gender transitions and identity.  
10  21.  Defendant Jay Inslee is the Governor of the State of Washington. As such, he must 
11  enforce the laws of that state. See Wash. Const. art. III, § 5. Governor Inslee also supervises the 
12  Department Secretary who administers SB 5599, and the Governor has the authority to remove 
13  the Secretary, as discussed below.  
14  22.  Governor Inslee signed SB 5599 on May 9, 2023.  
15  23.  Governor Inslee is sued in his official capacity.  
16  24.  Defendant Robert Ferguson is the Attorney General of Washington. As such, he is 
17  responsible for the legal defense of state statutes, including SB 5599. See Wash. Const. art. III, § 1; 
18  Wash. Rev. Code § 43.10.030.  
19  25.  Attorney General Ferguson is sued in his official capacity.  
20  26.  SB 5599 is administered by the Washington State Department of Children, Youth, 
21  and Families (“the Department” or “DCYF”).  
22  27.  The Department is an agency in the executive branch of the State of Washington. 
23  Wash. Rev. Code § 43.216.015.  
24  28.  Defendant Ross  Hunter is  Secretary  of the Washington State Department  of 
25  Children, Youth, and Families.  
26 
27 
 
Complaint - 4  Ard Law Group PLLC 
IPEC v. Inslee, No. 3:23-cv-5736  P.O. Box 11633 
Bainbridge Island, WA 98110 
Phone: (206) 701-9243 
 
 

Case 3:23-cv-05736-DGE   Document 1   Filed 08/16/23   Page 5 of 35
 
1  29.  Secretary Hunter “has the complete charge and supervisory powers over the 
2  department.” Wash. Rev. Code § 43.216.025; see also Matter of W.W.S., 469 P.3d 1190, 1204 
3  (Wash. Ct. App. 2020) (outlining the Secretary’s vast authority over the Department).  
4  30.  Secretary Hunter has authority over the Assistant Secretaries who issued the SB 
5  5599 implementation Memo discussed below.  
6  31.  Secretary Hunter was appointed by Governor Inslee, with the consent of the 
7  Washington State Senate, and serves at the pleasure of the Governor. See Wash. Rev. Code § 
8  43.216.025.  
9  32.  Secretary Hunter is sued in his official capacity.  
10  III.  Jurisdiction and Venue.  
11  33.  This case presents federal questions arising under the Constitution of the United 
12  States and also seeks relief for the deprivation of federal rights under color of state law. This Court 
13  accordingly has subject-matter jurisdiction pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331, 1343. 
14  34.  This Court has authority to award Plaintiffs declaratory relief pursuant to 28 U.S.C. 
15  § 2201, and injunctive relief under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1343, 2202, and Fed. R. Civ. P. 65. 
16  35.  Venue  is  proper  in  this  District  pursuant  to  28  U.S.C.  §  1391(b)  because  a 
17  substantial part of the facts complained of herein occurred within this District and because this 
18  District is the seat of government of the State of Washington and therefore Defendants are 
19  domiciled in this District.  
20  IV.  Facts.  
21  A.  Statutory Scheme.  
22  36.  During its most recent session, the Washington State Legislature enacted two 
23  statutes that amended Wash. Rev. Code § 13.32A.082. See 2023 Wash. Legis. Serv. Ch. 151 (SHB 
24  1406); 2023 Wash. Legis. Serv. Ch. 408 (ESSB 5599). Both acts went into effect on July 23, 2023. 
25  37.  SB 5599 modified the rights and procedures of Washington state law concerning 
26  parents in the upbringing and custody of their children.  
27 
 
Complaint - 5  Ard Law Group PLLC 
IPEC v. Inslee, No. 3:23-cv-5736  P.O. Box 11633 
Bainbridge Island, WA 98110 
Phone: (206) 701-9243 
 
 

Case 3:23-cv-05736-DGE   Document 1   Filed 08/16/23   Page 6 of 35
 
1  38.  In Washington, the baseline rule governing parental rights when children go to a 
2  shelter is that when a shelter “knows at the time of providing the shelter that the child is away from 
3  a lawfully prescribed residence or home without parental permission, it must contact the youth’s 
4  parent within 72 hours, but preferably within 24 hours, following the time that the youth is 
5  admitted  to  the  shelter  or  other  licensed  organization’s  program.”  Wash.  Rev.  Code  § 
6  13.32A.082(1)(b)(i). Further, that “notification must include the whereabouts of the youth, a 
7  description of the youth’s physical and emotional condition, and the circumstances surrounding 
8  the youth’s contact with the shelter or organization.” Id. 
9  39.  Thus, under this baseline rule, no later than 72 hours after a minor shows up at a 
10  shelter, parents must be told exactly where the child is, as well as how the child is and how the child 
11  ended up at the shelter, and the parents are free to go pick up their child and take him or her home. 
12  40.  The only exception to this statutorily imposed duty of shelters is that “[i]f there are 
13  compelling reasons not to notify the parent, the shelter or organization must instead notify the 
14  department”—that is, the state Department of Children, Youth and Families. Id. (emphasis 
15  added). Additionally, “compelling reasons” were previously defined as “circumstances that 
16  indicate that notifying the parent or legal guardian will subject the minor to abuse or neglect as 
17  defined in [another code section].” Id. § 13.32A.082(2)(c). 
18  41.  But SB 5599 expanded the definition of “compelling reasons” to now also include 
19  “[w]hen a minor is seeking or receiving protected health care services.” Id. § 13.32A.082(2)(c)(ii). 
20  And “‘protected health care services’ means “gender affirming treatment” as defined in [another 
21  code section].” Id. § 13.32A.082(2)(d). 
22  42.  In other words, to determine whether the exception to the baseline rule applies, 
23  there is no longer an inquiry into traditional abuse or neglect but merely a categorical triggering of 
24  “compelling reasons” whenever a minor shows up at a shelter seeking certain health services. Put 
25  another way, under SB 5599, a child merely showing up at a shelter or host home seeking or 
26  receiving “gender-affirming” treatment is legally equivalent to “circumstances that indicate”

1  B.  Notice.  
2  45.  These amendments appear to exempt from the usual parental notice requirement a 
3  scenario in which a minor is seeking or receiving protected health care services, since the action 
4  required in that specific scenario is covered by Subsection 3(b), which does not refer to parental 
5  notification. That conclusion is reinforced by the “commonplace” rule “of statutory construction 
6  that the specific governs the general.” City & Cnty. of S.F. v. Trump, 897 F.3d 1225, 1239 (9th Cir. 
7  2018) (quoting RadLAX Gateway Hotel, LLC v. Amalgamated Bank, 566 U.S. 639, 645 (2012)).  
8  46.  Additionally, reading Subsection 3(a), which applies to scenarios where there are 
9  compelling reasons not to notify parents, as simultaneously applying alongside Subsection 3(b), 
10  which specifies the subset of compelling reasons in which minors are seeking or receiving protected 
11  health services, would make 3(b)(ii) surplusage, since nearly the same thing is said in 3(a). Such 
12  interpretation would violate the fundamental rule of statutory interpretation that a court must “if 
13  possible . . . give effect to each word and clause in a statute.” United States v. Lopez, 998 F.3d 431, 
14  440 (9th Cir. 2021). Thus, a fair reading of the new statutory provision would authorize potentially 
15  life-changing medical treatments before notification to parents.

6  pronouns, or agree to allow the child to receive treatment that the child needs parental permission 
7  for but that the parents oppose.  
8  163.  To the extent SB 5599 is not clear in that regard, it is void for vagueness.  
9  164.  Plaintiffs have no adequate remedy at law. 
10  165.  The actions Defendants are now required to take violate federal law, specifically by 
11  posing a substantial threat to Plaintiffs’ right not to be deprived of any liberty interest without due 
12  process  of  law.  Absent  injunctive  relief,  Defendants’  actions  continue  to  threaten  to  harm 
13  Plaintiffs. 
14  H.  Count VIII: Washington Due Process Clause—Parents’ Right to Rear their Children 
15  Without State Interference; Wash. Const. Art. I, § 3.  
16  166.  Plaintiffs hereby incorporate the allegations made in each preceding paragraph of 
17  this Complaint as if fully set forth herein. 
18  167.  Under the Washington Constitution, “No person shall be deprived of life, liberty, 
19  or property, without due process of law.” Wash. Const. Art. I, § 3. 
20  168.  In the context of parental rights, the Washington Supreme Court has observed that 
21  “[t]he family entity is the core element upon which modern civilization is founded.” In re Custody 
22  of Smith, 969 P.2d 21, 28 (Wash. 1998), aff’d sub nom. Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57. And 
23  “parents[] . . . primarily have the constitutional right to the custody and control of such minor 
24  children.” In re Brown, 105 P.3d 991, 994 (Wash. 2005) (internal quotation marks omitted); see also 
25  In re Custody of B.M.H., 315 P.3d 470, 475 (Wash. 2013) (“[I]n . . . child custody disputes we afford 
26  considerable deference to parents . . . .”).

1  169.  Thus, because “[a] parent’s constitutionally protected right to rear his or her 
2  children  without  state  interference[]  .  .  .  [is]  as  a  fundamental  ‘liberty’  interest,”  “state 
3  interference is justified only if the state can show that it has a compelling interest and such 
4  interference is narrowly drawn to meet only the compelling state interest involved.” In re Custody 
5  of Smith, 969 P.2d at 28; see also In re Custody of Shields, 136 P.3d 117, 126 (Wash. 2006) (“[S]tate 
6  interference with a fit parent’s fundamental right to autonomy in child-rearing decisions is subject 
7  to strict scrutiny.”). 
8  170.  The  Defendants  cannot  satisfy  strict  scrutiny  here.  First,  there  cannot  be  a 
9  compelling government interest to deprive parents of their constitutional parental rights just 
10  because their child is receiving or seeking to receive “gender-affirming” care and shows up at a 
11  homeless shelter or host home. There is no connection to the parents’ behavior, and the State 
12  cannot have a compelling interest in displacing a parent unrelated to the parent’s conduct or 
13  condition. 
14  171.  Second, for the same reasons, SB 5599 is not narrowly tailored. It is overinclusive, 
15  sweeping in parents who are not neglectful or abusive into its net. If the law is concerned about 
16  problematic parents, then the law could be more narrowly tailored, as evidenced by the previous 
17  iteration where “compelling reasons” was defined to capture abusive or neglectful parents. 
18  172.  SB 5599 thus violates Plaintiffs’ parental rights under the Washington Constitution.  
19  173.  Plaintiffs have no adequate remedy at law. 
20  174.  The actions Defendants are now required to take violate state law, specifically by 
21  posing a substantial threat to Plaintiffs’ right not to be deprived of any liberty interest without due 
22  process  of  law.  Absent  injunctive  relief,  Defendants’  actions  continue  to  threaten  to  harm 
23  Plaintiffs.

1  176.  The Washington Constitution states, “No law shall be passed granting to any 
2  citizen, class of citizens, or corporation other than municipal, privileges or immunities which upon 
3  the same terms shall not equally belong to all citizens, or corporations.” Wash. Const. Art. I, § 12.  
4  177.  The  Washington  Supreme  Court  has  “construed  article  I,  section  12  of  the 
5  Washington Constitution to be consistent with the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth 
6  Amendment.” Wash. Food Indus. Ass’n & Maplebear, Inc. v. City of Seattle, 524 P.3d 181, 195 (Wash. 
7  2023) (citing Ockletree v. Franciscan Health Sys., 317 P.3d 1009, 1013-14 (Wash. 2014)). 
8  178.  However, “[t]he article I, section 12 reasonable ground test is more exacting than 
9  rational basis review.” Schroeder v. Weighall, 316 P.3d 482, 486 (Wash. 2014). “Under the 
10  reasonable ground test a court will not hypothesize facts to justify a legislative distinction.” Id. 
11  “Rather, the court will scrutinize the legislative distinction to determine whether it in fact serves 
12  the legislature’s stated goal.” Id. 
13  179.  The reasonable ground test is not satisfied here: because by lumping all parents of 
14  children who show up at shelters demanding or receiving “gender-affirming” treatment into one 
15  category, there is a mismatch between the legislature’s goal of helping children who are being 
16  mistreated by their parents and the parents covered by the law. And the law makes no attempt to 
17  sort these parents into different groups for differing treatment.  
18  180.  The law thus does not serve the legislature’s stated goal because it will separate 
19  children from parents when there is no need. SB 5599, therefore, violates Article I, Section 12 of 
20  the Washington Constitution. 
21  181.  Plaintiffs have no adequate remedy at law. 
22  182.  The actions Defendants are now required to take violate state law, specifically by 
23  posing a substantial threat to Plaintiffs’ right not to be deprived of any liberty interest without due 
24  process  of  law.  Absent  injunctive  relief,  Defendants’  actions  continue  to  threaten  to  harm 
25  Plaintiffs.

1  J.  Count X: Washington Free Speech Clause; Wash. Const. Art. I, § 5.  
2  183.  Plaintiffs hereby incorporate the allegations made in each preceding paragraph of 
3  this Complaint as if fully set forth herein. 
4  184.  The Washington Constitution declares, “Every person may freely speak, write and 
5  publish on all subjects, being responsible for the abuse of that right.” Wash. Const. Art. I, § 5. 
6  185.  The clause provides that “parents have a right to determine the manner in which 
7  delicate moral issues will be discussed with their young children.” Bering v. SHARE, 721 P.2d 918, 
8  937 (Wash. 1986); see also id. (“The parents’ right to direct the rearing of their children clearly is 
9  deserving of the State’s protection.”). 
10  186.  SB 5599 violates this clause of the Washington Constitution by violating parents’ 
11  rights to teach and discuss the “delicate moral issues” surrounding gender identity. It does so in 
12  two ways. 
13  187.  First, it chills parental speech both before a child runs away, when the parent is 
14  trying to get the child back, and after the child has been returned. SB 5599 will force parents to 
15  avoid any speech that their child or the State may disagree with, such as using the child’s biological 
16  pronouns and birth name, or affirming the child’s chosen gender identity. 
17  188.  Second, SB 5599 compels parents to engage in speech contrary to the parents’ views 
18  on “delicate moral issues” that align with their child and the State’s views. 
19  189.  SB 5599 does all this by creating a legal environment wherein if the parent does not 
20  do what the child wants, the child can just run away and get the state to provide what the child 
21  desires. And once that has occurred, for the parents to convince the State to reunify the child with 
22  them, the parents must confirm through their speech the State’s views on gender identity and 
23  avoid saying anything to their child with which the State disagrees. 
24  190.  Thus, SB 5599 violates Article I, Section 5 of the Washington Constitution. 
25  191.  Plaintiffs have no adequate remedy at law. 
26  192.  The actions Defendants are now required to take violate state law, specifically by 
27  posing a substantial threat to Plaintiffs’ right not to be deprived of any liberty interest without due
